title: E11: From Decision Support to AI Integration: Navigating BI's Evolution with Donald Farmer

cleanText:
Donald, thanks so much for coming on.

It's a great pleasure, thank you.

I thought we'd start. It's going to be a broad-ranging conversation about business intelligence, um, machine learning era, and then where we're headed with language models. When you were launching Power BI, I'd love for you to just set the stage for us. What was the field of business intelligence like, even pre sort of machine learning in the Predictive Analytics era when you were launching, uh, you know, the seminal Power BI product?

You know, it was, um, the evolution had been pretty long. It was this fairly long evolution to get to where we were, um, with products like, um, Par Pivot, Power BI. Uh, it had come out of data warehousing, which itself had come out of the concept of management information systems, which themselves had come out of the concept of decision support systems. So we'd had this, this growing sort of sense and, and, and technical kind of development of how do you centralize, very much it was all about centralization. How do you centralize the data in an organization so that it can be analyzed? And, um, we added business intelligence on top of that. That was a term that was again introduced by Howard, um, of Gartner, um, that was sort of pretty interesting, Howard Dresner. And then, um, people started to say, "Well, reports aren't good enough, so we need these interactive dashboards." From that point, as the tools became easier, we then had self-service. And so at this particular point, around 2005, 2008, you had the development of real self-service tools, which enabled business users to essentially do their own work. Uh, the phrase that was used was "with or without it" permission. And that, um, that was happening. Now, that had to a certain extent always happened in Excel. Now it was happening in, uh, bespoke tools for, for doing this, this kind of analysis. Predictive Analytics was something which had been a, a specialization. We had Predictive Analytics in the kind of world of SAS, who which was used primarily by, um, scientists, data scientists, and statisticians. You had SPSS, which had acquired by IBM, which was focused, it was a statistical package for social sciences, SPSS. So it was used a lot by social scientists and historians and people like that. So that was a specialized area. And it was just this sense that there was now enough power, there was enough power in a desktop, especially because of 64-bit computing, there was enough memory, there was enough storage, you could actually start to do some of this work yourself. And the, the really compelling question was, "What does that mean to do this work yourself? What are you actually going to do? Are you going to build dashboards that you're going to share with everyone? Are you going to replace the IT function of creating the corporate system of record, or is it more for sort of personal exploration and analysis?" And I think the latter was, was really the compelling story at the time. We didn't want to replace it, that wasn't the, um, that wasn't the purpose. It was to enable sort of personal exploration and analysis with better quality, um, and more insight than you have before. So that's kind of where we were at that point.

And, and as far as our, our listeners are concerned, I think the, the interesting part of your, your talk on, you know, evolution and how we have been moving through these different deltas in, in decision-making and business intelligence, ranging from, you know, just getting the data centralized in warehouses, and then, "Wow, once it's centralized, what can we do with that information?" It, there's always a through line, which is the, the, the goal of many goals was generally to put the data in front of key decision-makers to provide enough, you know, ample context in order to make decisions. Is that, is that fair? Is that, is that basically?

Yeah, that's absolutely true. I mean, um, you know, so I said we're talking about business intelligence, Predictive Analytics, which came out of data warehousing, which came out of management information systems, which came out of decision support systems. And it turns out that decision support is still what we're doing all these, these years later. We're still trying to help business people make better decisions. Um, and so the, I actually prefer the term decision support because it, it at least tells you what the software does. It supports you in making decisions. Who knows what business intelligence means? Sort of a vague term. So, um, I, I'm so interested in that. That's a good distinction because I think as our conversation goes on, I think we will start to make that distinction a little clearer because I, I agree in the sense that business intelligence just as a term can, can mean what you want it to mean, right? Is, is this where the intelligence of the business lives? Is, is the platform itself the intelligence, or is it providing me with data to make me intelligent? So the idea of decision support, I think, is much more concise, providing that context to make decisions. So on that note, what are the kinds of decisions that people are, are trying to make with these business intelligence tools? Like, what goes into making these decisions, and how is the machine learning and AI supporting that?

It's, of course, the range of decisions that are made is absolutely huge. There's, but you can think of it, you can structure the thinking about decisions in three categories, broad categories. Um, there are, um, strategic decisions, which are, you know, which, um, which new industry are we going to enter? If you're a conglomerate, which new market are we going to open? Are we going to move into, you know, the Asian market, or what offices are we going to close, what stores are we going to open? Big questions, and you can think of them as having each individual question has very, very high business value, relatively speaking. There's very few of them, and those are strategic decisions. The very opposite end of the scale, there are decisions where they have relatively small business value. What discount do I offer this customer? Who do I call next? What do I do about this alarm? Um, each one has relatively small business value in the big scheme of things, but of course, there are millions of those decisions in, in a typical business. So that's the very opposite end. Um, those are operational decisions. So relatively low value, but a large number. There's a kind of process of aggregation as you move from operational to strategic, um, data is aggregated, decisions become, um, made at higher levels in the organization, and there are typically more data sources involved. So data becomes more diverse. And in the middle, between the operational and strategic, you have this kind of tactical decision-making, the decisions of middle managers who are taking all the operational information, aggregating it up, and making decisions for the medium term. And those decisions themselves may then feed into strategic decisions in the future. So where is, um, business intelligence working? Business intelligence primarily, historically, has worked with the tactical decision-making of the middle managers. Increasingly, we're seeing business intelligence being pushed down into operational decisions through embedded analytics, for example. And I think with the advent of, um, AI, we're starting to see some of the potentially strategic decision-making being informed by analytics, rather than driven by analytics, but at least being informed by it. But the sweet spot is still this, this center of, um, tactical decision-making.

Donald, uh, I remember a distinct moment, pre-COVID, we, uh, we were discussing the state of BI, and you ended up saying, you know, the pace of innovation was just slowing. You had said a lot of just seeing the same stuff again and again in terms of different, you know, same ETL tooling or same visualization. A lot of these categories were just mature, uh, you, the growth rates were slowing. A lot of products were differentiating on a feature-by-feature basis. And then we had LLMs. And so maybe could talk a little bit just at a high level, what new energy and principles, uh, language models have created, um, in this market that, you know, towards the end of the decade was actually thought to be fairly mature, um, both by practitioners and investors alike?

Yeah, I think, um, I think I was right before COVID. I mean, I, the market was kind of slowing down precisely because there were no new, um, scenarios opening up. And it's new scenarios opening up which then drives technological development, um, or equally, technological development can open up new scenarios. And that just wasn't happening. And we haven't, in particular, we haven't solved this problem of how to get into strategic decision-making. We absolutely knew how to push analytics and even to a certain extent automation down into operational decision-making, but not into the, the high business value area of strategic decision-making. And one of the reasons for that is because that decision-making is actually, when you think about it, it's all about language. Um, we often talk about, you know, businesses being driven by data and so on, but we've all seen those business meetings where there's a slide on screen, there's some data, but 90% of what is discussed is not on screen, it's not in the slide, it's not in the data, it's the conversation that happens around the table. "Well, here's a business trend, but now let's have an hour's discussion about what that trend means." That's language. That's what drives the higher-level decisions. So what's really interesting about LLMs is they actually provide a way of providing a data-driven input to that language, and they become either assistants, or they become advisors, or they're able to find patterns and put them in language terms. And what this means then is that they can become, um, if you like, part of that conversation. And that's really...

Sorry, no, please.

Well, I want to say, I think that's a really interesting phase that we're getting at is where the, the LLM enables the analytic process to become a team member of the decision-making organization. That's a, that's a sort of slightly, um, fanciful way of describing it, but I actually think that is the fundamental shift that we see.

So the, would you say then that the, the percolation of data-driven or decision support moving from the, the middle layer, the technical layer, to strategic, would you say that it was more that the technology had, the LLM technology had empowered movement towards strategic decision-making, or would you say it was more on the side of more people were trying to make strategic decisions, um, in that time period, and LLMs just kind of happened to be around and people latched on to it, or would you say it was a little bit of a two-way synchronous there?

Well, I think that's a great point. Um, LLMs really came about at a, at a very convenient time, at a, at a very, um, at a point that was already pivotal in, in the history of business, I think, and in the history of business decision-making, which is that we came out of this dramatic crisis, and of course, there had been during COVID a lot of changes of strategy, most of which was thinking on our feet, you know, there was, there was, um, that really was an emergency. Coming out of the emergency, there was this need for a, a completely new strategic view of the world that, that, that had to happen. And then along comes this new tool at exactly the time when we need to take the strategic view of the world. Now, to be fair, the tool is still somewhat behind. LLMs are still somewhat behind the strategic need, but you can see this, this happening. You can see this trend already that, um, every analytics company, every analytics tool set is integrating LLMs as a way of providing higher-level insight and deeper insight, um, precisely because people have to make those decisions. And I think you're right, there are more of these decisions that have to be made just now, partly as we adapt to the world post-COVID, and of course, as we adapt to the world of LLMs, we also have to now make decisions. So it becomes a sort of virtuous cycle, I think, that that's driving the very rapid developments that we're seeing just now.

Any examples, Donald, uh, specific use cases of strategic, higher-level insight in terms of demos, etc., or lines of business you're seeing transformed by this newer wave of BI that have really, uh, given you pause or gotten you excited?

Lines of business are, um, which are super affected by this, I think, are going to be areas like, um, supply chain management, which is an enormously complex field. And trying to understand, my favorite example of this was, um, you know, this, the ship getting stuck in the Suez Canal, which was, you know, blocking the Suez Canal, the world's most, you know, important shipping lane. And that was a fun week, I think, all around. That was a fun week for everyone watching. That was an interesting and fun week to learn about supply chain management. It, it really was. And, um, you suddenly discovered overnight how extremely fragile the world's supply chains were, actually. You kind of realized how robust they had been before and how fragile they were now that this just-in-time, um, process was actually in many ways kind of miraculous that it worked and and achieved so much, but it was fragile. And, um, one of the problems with supply chain analysis, it's so immensely complex. There are so many variables within that. And as you margins come down and down, knowledge of those variables, being able to manage those variables becomes more and more important. We can't, we won't go back to a system where we just oversupply, overstock in order to to manage this. We're still going to be doing just-in-time supply chain management. We just need to do it with, with more and more smarts. And I think it's been fascinating to see, um, I think it's been fascinating to see artificial intelligence playing its role in supply chain management. So that's a, that's a whole area, as a line of business, it's a whole area of business which I think is being affected. And then there are some other areas. Um, I think we're all kind of familiar already with it being used in, in areas like marketing, which seems like a very obvious sort of field for it, especially if we're talking about LLMs because LLMs are our language. I think we see it in, in fields like HR as well, um, where we're, where we're dealing with human beings, that's important. But I do think when it comes down to the, um, the, the business functions that are going to be most affected, I think you're going to see, um, the, the business function primarily of supply chain management, and in our world, you know, the kind of tech world, we're going to see coding and development greatly affected by, by LLMs.

So longtime listeners of the show know, probably might guess what I'm, what I'm going to say next because I'm on record saying this a lot, but what a lot of what you're saying kind of gives credence to the idea that LLMs are, at least at their core, and how people when they think about how to use an LLM, they are phenomenal reasoning agents. They are reasoning machines more than they are thinking machines, right? LLMs have shown that they can encode knowledge and recall knowledge, you know, when asked, that, that's not really up for, they can do that. However, where they truly shine, where they truly provide the most value, seems to be when you do this warehousing, you centralize this data, you aggregate this data, and then you to kind of use your analogy a little bit here, just in time, provide this context to the LLM with a surrounding context question, let's say a business intelligence question, and say, "What do you think we should be doing?" That AI in the room, um, that analogy that you were giving earlier, uh, is that, is that true? Is that how you think about LLMs acting here?

Is that, um, I don't think of them that way. I don't think of them as either reasoning or thinking. Um, I, I think of them as remixing, the remixing. They are remixing what the information that they have, and that is what they're brilliantly good at doing. They're fantastically good at remixing. Um, I think that you can actually see that they, in a sense, that they can't reason, um, or they have to be told how to reason, and they can be told how to reason by human beings who know how to reason and can walk them through the steps, and then they can do it. Um, the example I always want to give here, uh, just kind of off the wall a little bit, is, um, do you remember the, the, the chimpanzees that, that could learn...


To speak, they could do sign language and things like that. There was Washoe and things like that, and it was always amazing to see them. There was a parrot, you know, 100 words or whatever. And yet, when you look at those animals doing that, 99% of the effort, the energy, the insight, and the intelligence that went into that conversation was on the human side. You know, none of these chimpanzees ever woke up saying, "Hey, I want to speak to a human being. I wonder if I can do it this way." It was all the human being doing that effort. When you see LLMs doing amazing things, mostly behind that, there is a human being who has put the effort in to make the LLM do it, and then it's able to do it. And we get so amazed by the LLM doing it that we forget that there's a huge amount of human effort, of intelligence structure, went into that. So when you see LLMs doing mathematics, solving mathematical theorems, coming up with new theorems, which I think is amazing, um, but there's a human being who has given that structure so that the LLM can then remix the knowledge it's been given in this fascinating way. And so I think of them always as remixing engines rather than having their own reasoning.

And my favorite example, um, to show this to you or for you to try yourself, um, I think actually I see me doing this, um, is ask it to do something like, "Give me a seven-letter synonym of the word happy," or "seven-letter synonyms of the word happy." And any of the common engines, they'll give you some, but they'll also give you a whole pile of synonyms which don't have seven letters; they have five, they have six, they have nine. And then you can reason with it and say, "Well, why, you know, you've got nine here, and there's seven here, five there? Why is that happening?" And the LLM will very helpfully respond, "Oh, my mistake, I'll try again." And it does exactly the same thing again, comes out with a different list with, you know, more mistakes. And then you go back in, you know, "Give me a list of synonyms, and for every synonym, count the letters, and then only output the ones which have seven letters." Still can't do it, still can't do it. But the reason it can't do that is because certain synonyms, like "and content," um, would be so strong that it, it just can't do that. You know, "delighted" is such a strong synonym for happy that that waiting in the system completely overweights the rule, "Don't output anything that doesn't have seven letters." And, um, that's, that's why it's not particularly reasoning; it's remixing. And I think if you think of it as a remixing technology, um, it gives you more insight, or it gives you, I think, more useful insight, rather than thinking of it as a reasoning technology.

I like that word. I like, I like that word a lot, Donald, remixing, because even when I do my own kind of lectures on the topic, and I say, "You know, reasoning, overthinking," obviously at a very high level, my immediate next slide is, "Now, let's watch me ask it how many syllables are in the phrase 'Golden Gate Bridge,' and let's watch it get it fantastically wrong," right? And I'll do a lot of examples like that. Like I'll say, "Here's a relatively simple math problem, you know, x * you know, 140 * 78 plus the remainder of 22 divided by 21," and I was like, "Don't write code, don't reason through it, just tell me the answer." And then it'll give me the answer wrong, but pretty close. And then I say, "Actually, think about it step by step," and then it will get it right and say, "Oh, my, you've done that effort, you've put..." But I'm the one who did the effort to say, "I'm telling you how to solve this problem." So the, the, the active reasoning, and I think, you know, to remix what I was saying earlier, uh, a lot of that just-in-time context is not just data from a warehouse, but it's also the steps in which the human wants to take in order to make that decision. Uh, so I think that remixing makes a lot of sense.

And there's another part of this that we, you know, people worry a lot about hallucinations, and, um, you know, hallucinations, um, from, from AI, of course, typically mean things that don't exist, or things which are just, you know, totally out of there, totally, totally wrong. And you see, of course, pictures of people holding coffee cups, and they've got seven fingers, whatever. And then we're told that these are hallucinations from the AI. I think it's important to remember that in a sense, everything that AI produces is a hallucination. If AI produces a picture of somebody holding a coffee cup with five fingers, um, or four fingers and a thumb, the process of doing that is exactly the same as a process of doing seven fingers, two thumbs. It's just it happened to get it right. There's nothing substantially different. When it produces a hallucination, it's just that it hasn't had enough examples to produce a real one. So there's no difference in the process. Now, when a human being hallucinates, there's something wrong, there's something wrong in your urology or, or, or in your, your senses. So, um, there's actually something different when a human being hallucinates as opposed to human, human being perceiving in a normal way. There's something different going on when an AI hallucinates as opposed to getting it right. It's just that the information that is remixing is different, and it doesn't have enough, or has too many sources, or it's, but, but there's nothing necessarily going wrong. And I, I think that's, I think that's actually important to understand, that in the sense, the AI is getting it wrong, but it's getting it wrong by exactly the same process as it got it right. So when it gets it right, that is just as, as random, if you like, as, as getting it wrong.

Yeah, I wanted to use that in the context of the Suez Canal example, Donald, because I like it as an example of decision-making, because we take that crisis, there's everything there, there's a lot of downstream implications, there's the strategic to mid-level to tactical inside. If we use that example, I really like this analogy of LLMs as just-in-time context for every decision-making at every level. And so if we take, uh, sort of, uh, that example, I could imagine, you know, a lot of just being aggregated at your fingertips. So you think about the whole data prep layer, essentially a lot of slide making, a lot of Excel reporting, a lot of dashboarding, um, please, we call them vector databases now, AI Integration, BI, Power BI, machine learning, language models, AI, data warehousing, self-service BI, predictive analytics, AI, strategic decision-making, a lot of preparation essentially being completely transformed, and a whole swath of the business intelligence, you know, tooling ecosystem being changed as a result of this. Are, are there any, um, who is, which parts of the tool chains are the big winners in this, uh, new LLM world, and which parts are going to have to rethink their business?

If you think about a lot of the, like, legacy or existing business intelligence players, I'm curious that just-in-time context actually has pretty radical implications for their customers. So would love to get your perspective on, on that. I think the people who really suffer here are the, um, the architectures that require data to be extracted and loaded. These, these processes, ETL, that I spent so long in my career building, but the idea that I'm going to extract data, transform it into a particular kind of model, and then load it, and then I'm just going to run a set of decisions from that because I got the model right in the first place, and now I build a data warehouse which is going to last for 10 years, and it's going to be, you know, I'm going to make decisions of it. That model is, is completely broken now. It always was to a certain extent broken because it was never really possible to predict in advance all the questions that might be asked in a system. And you know, when we think about data quality that you mentioned, you know, there's no real measure of data quality; the only measure of data quality is, is it fit for purpose? And if the first purpose changes, then the data is no longer fit for that purpose or for the new purpose, and therefore the quality which was good last week is now no longer good. Um, and so anyone who's building architectures that are based on that principle, that you can define in advance what it is you want to do, therefore you can build the appropriate model, and it's going to have some kind of lifetime because the process of building it is so long that it has to have a lifetime to make it worthwhile doing, um, I think they're in real trouble. So I think traditional ETL, I think traditional warehouse models are, are in real trouble.

Are they in trouble in the sense that they need to, like, I guess, is it as simple as, at a high level, that these traditional ETL pipelines need to now incorporate new methodologies for aggregation, specifically for LLMs or some other kind of AI process, or is it in the sense that the fundamental techniques and and tooling behind each ETL, it's just there's no way to fix it, we have to start over from scratch? I guess where, where are we on that spectrum of how to fix that problem? They do, they do need to adapt to some of the new demands. In other words, they need to know how to load vector databases. That's, that's what seems like a fairly obvious thing. There are some things like that that they must be able to do.
